title.text: The FINITE STRING Newsletter Abstracts of Current Literature

entities.text: FINITE STRING Newsletter Abstracts of Current Literature

datasetContent.text: 19th Annual ACL Conf., The process of assigning a referent to a pronoun can be viewed as utilizing two kinds of strategies.
One strategy is concerned with selecting the best referent from among the candidates available.
The other strategy is concerned with searching through memory for the candidates.
These two types of strategies, which will be referred to mnemonically as inference and search strategies, have different kinds of characteristics.
A search strategy dictates the order in which candidates are evaluated, but has no machinery for carrying out the evaluation.
The inference strategy helps to setup the representation of the information in the text against which candidates can be evaluated, but has noway of finding the candidates.
In this paper, the way these strategies might interact is explored and the results of two studies that bear on the issues are reported on.
